section.title: Introduction
section.para:
The
scons-gnu-build package is an extension to
SCons which makes it behaving more like a GNU build system. We aim at achieving better interoperability between external development utilities (such as packaging tools, e.g.
debian ones' ) and scons scripts. The goal is to reduce the amount of work needed to integrate scons-based projects with this external world and simplify some rather common tasks (such as installation or packaging).

section.title: GVars basics
section.para: GVars are "special variables" accessible from outside of scons script. In general, GVar is an object which associates up to three entities:

listitem.para:
a SCons
construction variable (
env['var'] = val ),

a SCons
command line variable (
scons var=val ), and

a SCons
command line option (
scons --opt val ).

section.para:
With GVars we maintain abstract variables whose values are settable via scons command line and are passed to scons environment automagically. Command line variables or options act as inputs for GVars whereas construction variables are their destination points. The situation is depicted on
where two GVars
a and
b are shown together with their associated variables.

Some modules use GVars to implement standard GNU variables such as the variables for installation directories (see
). In this section we focus on the general GVar concept and explain the way of defining your own GVars.

GVars are implemented in
GVars submodule: from SConsGnu import GVars Their usage is basically a three step procedure:

listitem.para:
Commit declarations to create actual variables, see
.

Update SCons environment with variable values,
.

section.para: You may further access (read and modify) the values of GVars in your SCons environment via so-called proxy objects. In the following subsections we will explain all these steps and techniques.

section.title: Declaring GVars
section.para:
The first step of the procedure outlined in previous subsection is to declare GVars. The goal is to prepare the whole collection of GVar declarations for further processing. Four factory methods are provided for this purpose. The first two named
GVarDecl and
GVarDeclU create an object representing a single GVar declaration. The other two named
GVarDecls and
GVarDeclsU create multiple declarations at once returning dict-like collection where GVar names are mapped onto their declarations. The dictionary is a kind of flat namespace which encloses multiple GVar declarations. In steps 2. and 3. of the previously outlined procedure we will actually need this dict object.

section.title: Declaring single GVars
section.para:
Single GVar declaration may be created with either
GVarDecl or
GVarDeclU . The prototype of
GVarDecl is

The function creates GVar declaration according to three parameters:
env_decl ,
var_decl , and
opt_decl . All the parameters are optional and if you wish to skip any of them, just set it to
None : decl = GVarDecl(env_decl, None, opt_decl) or use only relevant named parameters: decl = GVarDecl(env_decl = env_decl, opt_decl = opt_decl)

example.title: Declaring single GVar
example.para:
Let's create a string-valued variable which obtains it's value from option
--xvar and stores in construction variable named
xvar :
example.programlisting: from SConsGnu.GVars import GVarDecl decl = GVarDecl( {'xvar' : None}, None, ('--xvar', {'dest' : 'xvar', 'type' : 'string'}) )
example.para:
The above code creates a new GVar declaration which associates scons environment variable named
xvar with a CLI option
--xvar . The default value for environment variable is
None (it's indicated by
{'xvar' : None} in the above snippet). The command line variable is skipped, i.e. we do not associate our GVar with command-line variable. The command line option is named
--xvar and holds its value in an internal attribute named
xvar (the
{'dest' : 'xvar'} item). The option's type is
string .

section.para:
The parameters to
GVarDecl are summarized in the following table:

tr.td:
tuple or
dict

td.para:
A
(name, default) tuple or one-entry dict
{name : default} . This data is used to initialize associated construction variable. The variable is initialized with
env.SetDefault(name = default) , where
env is the destination scons environment.

tr.td:
tuple or
dict

td.para:
Declaration parameters used when adding the corresponding command-line variable. If
var_decl is a tuple, it must have the form: ( key [, help, default, validator, converter, kw ] ), where entries in square brackets are optional. The consecutive elements are interpreted in order shown above as
key ,
help ,
default ,
validator ,
converter ,
kw . The meaning of these arguments is same as for
SCons.Variables.Variables.Add() . The
kw , if present, must be a dictionary.

If
var_decl is a dictionary it should have the form
{ 'key' : 'foo', 'help' : 'Help for foo', ... } . The
'kw' , if present, must be a dictionary. The arguments enclosed in the dictionary are later passed verbatim to
SCons.Variables.Variables.Add() as keyword arguments.

tr.td:
tuple ,
list or
dict

td.para:
Declaration parameters used when adding the associated
SCons command-line option . If
opt_decl is a tuple or list, it must have the form:
(names, args) or
[names, args] where
names is a string or tuple of option names (e.g.
"-f --file" or
('-f', '--file') ) and
args is a dictionary defining the remaining
option attributes . The entire
opt_decl may be for example
tuple( ('-f','--file-name'), { 'action' : "store", 'dest' : "file_name" } ) .

If
opt_decl is a dictionary, it should have following form (keys are relevant, values are just examples):
{ 'names' : ("-f", "--file-name"), 'action' : 'store', 'type' : 'string', 'dest' : 'file_name', ... } . The parameters enclosed in
opt_decl dictionary are passed verbatim to
SCons.Script.Main.AddOption() . Note, that the
dest parameter is required.

section.para:
Sometimes, when using
GVarDecl we have to repeat some data. For example, default values for construction variable and command line variable are usually same. The same applies to
help strings which in most cases are identical for both, the command line variable and option. Because we use different parametrs to describe command line variable and environment variable we have to type the default value or help string twice. To avoid such a code duplication one may use functions with a "unified" interface, in this case the
GVarDeclU function.

The
GVarDeclU has the following prototype
section.programlisting: _GVarDecl GVarDeclU(env_key = None, var_key = None, opt_key = None, default = None, help = None, validator = None, converter = None, option = None, type = None, opt_default = None, metavar = None, nargs = None, choices = None, action = None, const = None, callback = None, callback_args = None, callback_kwargs = None)
section.para: Each of its parameters is mapped to an appropriate parameters in associated variables. If we denote by ENV the corresponding construction variable, by VAR the corresponding command line variable, and by OPT the corresponding command line option, then all the above parameters are mapped to their counterparts in ENV, VAR and OPT as shown in the following table

None the GVar variable is not associated with command line option.

opt_default parameter for command-line option.

Option strings, e.g.
"--option" ,
"--option -o" or

example.title: Declaring single GVar with GVarDeclU
example.para:
In the following example, we declare same GVar as in
, this time using
GVarDeclU :
example.programlisting: from SConsGnu.GVars import GVarDeclU decl = GVarDeclU(env_key = 'xvar', opt_key = 'xvar', option = '--xvar', type = 'string')
example.para: As you may see, this notation is a little bit more compact than the previous one.

section.para: To this end we have created an object which represents single GVar declaration. It's kind an isolated and we can't do with it much more than determine the associated objects (ENV, VAR, OPT) and their properties. More useful things can be done once we collect all our GVars together. This is the matter of next subsections.

section.title: Declaring multiple GVars
section.para:
The GVar workflow assumes that there is a point when all GVar declarationss get collected together. At this point we have a complete information for the next step in the three-step procedure outlined in
. Having all GVars in a single dictionary we may commit them to create actual variables.

There is a special class named
_GVarDecls which represents a collection of GVar declarations. It's a kind of dict, but it also adds few methods on its own. The
SConsGnu.GVars module provides two factory methods to create such collections, these are
GVarDecls and
GVarDeclsU .

The
GVarDecl function supports several forms of invocation. Here we give just a couple of examples, the complete reference may be found in API documentation.

example.title: Using GVarDecls with a dict of objects
example.para:
In the following example we declare two GVars:
foo and
bar .
example.programlisting: from SConsGnu.GVars import GVarDecls, GVarDecl # create single declarations foodecl = GVarDecl( {'ENV_FOO' : 'default ENV_FOO'}, # ENV ('var_foo', 'var_foo help', ), # VAR ('--foo', {'dest' : "opt_foo"}) ) # OPT bardecl = GVarDecl( {'ENV_BAR' : None}, # ENV ('var_bar', 'var_bar help', 'default var_bar'), # VAR ('--bar', {'dest':"opt_bar", "type":"string"})) # OPT # put them all together decls = GVarDecls({ 'foo' : foodecl, 'bar' : bardecl })
example.para:
The keys in the above hash are GVar names. Values are objects representing GVar declarations. Note, that in this example we use different names for ENV, VAR and OPT. For example, the construction variable (ENV) for GVar
foo is named
ENV_FOO , the command line variable (VAR) is named
var_foo , and the option key is
opt_foo .

section.para:
You don't have to create each GVar declaration separatelly before putting all your GVars to a collection. Instead, you may simply put declaration arguments as parameters to GVarDecls and they will be passed to
GVarDecl for you. With this, the
may be refactored to the following form.

example.title: Using GVarDecls with bare parameters
example.programlisting: from SConsGnu.GVars import GVarDecls # create multiple declarations at once decls = GVarDecls({ # GVar 'foo' 'foo' : ( {'ENV_FOO' : 'default ENV_FOO'}, # ENV ('var_foo', 'var_foo help', ), # VAR ('--foo', {'dest' : "opt_foo"}) ), # OPT # GVar 'bar' 'bar' : ( {'ENV_BAR' : None}, # ENV ('var_bar', 'var_bar help', 'default var_bar'), # VAR ('--bar', {'dest':"opt_bar", "type":"string"}) ) # OPT })

section.para:
We may also pass a list (instead of dict) as an argument to
GVarDecls , for example

example.title: Using GVarDecls with arrays
example.programlisting: from SConsGnu.GVars import GVarDecls decls = GVarDecls([ # GVar 'foo' ('foo', ( {'ENV_FOO' : 'default ENV_FOO'}, # ENV ('var_foo', 'var_foo help', ), # VAR ('--foo', {'dest' : "opt_foo"}) )), # OPT # GVar 'bar' ('bar', ( {'ENV_BAR' : None}, # ENV ('var_bar', 'var_bar help', 'default var_bar'), # VAR ('--bar', {'dest':"opt_bar", "type":"string"}) )) # OPT ])

section.para: The third "cannonical" form of invocation is to use keyword arguments, that is our variables foo and bar may be declared as follows

example.title: Using GVarDecls with keyword arguments
example.programlisting: from SConsGnu.GVars import GVarDecls decls = GVarDecls( # GVar 'foo' foo = ( {'ENV_FOO' : 'default ENV_FOO'}, # ENV ('var_foo', 'var_foo help', ), # VAR ('--foo', {'dest' : "opt_foo"}) ), # OPT # GVar 'bar' bar = ( {'ENV_BAR' : None}, # ENV ('var_bar', 'var_bar help', 'default var_bar'), # VAR ('--bar', {'dest':"opt_bar", "type":"string"}) ) # OPT )

section.para: Of course the keyword arguments may be appended to normal arguments, so the syntaxes of dict, list and keyword arguments may be mixed.

example.title: Using GVarDecls with array and keyword arguments
example.programlisting: from SConsGnu.GVars import GVarDecls decls = GVarDecls( # GVar 'foo' [('foo',( {'ENV_FOO' : 'ENV default FOO'}, # ENV ('FOO', 'FOO variable help', ), # VAR ('--foo', {'dest' : "opt_foo"}) ))], # OPT # GVar 'geez' geez = ( {'ENV_GEEZ' : None}, # ENV ('GEEZ', 'GEEZ variable help', 'VAR default GEEZ'), # VAR ('--geez', {'dest':"opt_geez", "type":"string"})) # OPT )

section.para:
Because
_GVarDecls collection is a dict, it has this nice feature that we can remove, add declarations or merge multiple
_GVarDecls collections. That means, we don't have to declare all the variables in a single call, but may spread out this task among multiple SConscripts.

GVarDecls inherits from
GVarDecl the feature that some data may have to be repeated. For those, who want a more compact notation, we provide the
GVarDeclsU method which accepts the "unified" parameters.

example.title: Using GVarDeclsU
example.para:
In this example we create variables foo and bar similar to
this time using
GVarDeclsU .
example.programlisting: from SConsGnu.GVars import GVarDeclsU decls = GVarDeclsU( foo = { 'env_key': 'ENV_FOO', 'var_key' : 'var_foo', 'opt_key' : 'opt_foo', 'option' : '--foo', 'default' : 'Default FOO', 'help' : 'foo help' }, bar = { 'env_key': 'ENV_BAR', 'var_key' : 'var_bar', 'opt_key' : 'opt_bar', 'option' : '--bar', 'default' : 'Default VAR', 'type' : 'string', 'help' : 'bar help' } )

section.para:
In the above example we've used keyword arguments, but all the calling conventions of
GVarDecls (that is passing list or dict, or mixing them with keyword arguments) apply also to
GVarDeclsU .

section.title: Default values and substitutions
section.para:
When declaring a GVar variable one may define default values for the associated construction variable, command line variable and command line option. One feature of GVars is that they support substitutions similarly as the construction variables do. Taking construction variables as an example, if you have two construction variables
foo and
bar and you write # SConstruct env = Environment() env['foo'] = "foo married $bar" env['bar'] = "BAR" print env.subst("foo: $foo") print env.subst("bar: $bar") then you should expect at output ptomulik@tea:$ scons -Q foo: foo married BAR bar: BAR scons: `.' is up to date.
Substitutions may also be used in default values of command line variables and comand line options.

example.title: Substitutions in default values
example.para:
Let's say, you have defined GVar variables
foo and
bar as follows: from SConsGnu.GVars import GVarDecls decls = GVarDecls( foo = ( { 'ENV_FOO' : None }, ('VAR_FOO', 'Help for VAR_FOO', '$VAR_BAR'), None), bar = ( { 'ENV_BAR' : None }, ('VAR_BAR', 'Help for VAR_BAR', 'BAR'), None), ) then after commiting
decls and updating the scons environment
env you should expect the following construction variables in environment env['ENV_FOO'] == '${ENV_BAR}' # True env['ENV_BAR'] == 'BAR' # True

section.para:
The substitution machinery leaves the core job to SCons Environment. What GVars do by their own is to just catch and forward appropriatelly to the scons environment the variable substitutions found in command line variables or options. In the above example the
VAR_FOO='$VAR_BAR' contains a substitution of existing command line variable
VAR_BAR , so the substitution
'$VAR_BAR' in default value of
VAR_FOO will be forwarded to environment as
'${ENV_BAR}' .

section.title: Committing GVar declarations
section.para:
Once created, GVar declarations shall be committed with
_GVarDecls.Commit() method. By committing declarations you create their associatted commandline options and variables, construction variables, fill them with default values and freeze the declarations such that it's guaranteed that they will not change. The
Commit method optionally spawns the actual GVar variables (to this end we talked about variable "declarations", not the variables) which may be used to pass values between commandline options/variables and scons environment. The result of commit is a new collection of GVar variables - an object of type
_GVars . Once
_GVars variables are created, the
_GVarDecls collection is no longer needed.

example.title: Committing GVar declarations
example.para:
Having a collection
decls of GVar declarations, we may commit them as follows vars = decls.Commit(env,vars) where env is an instance of
SCons Environment object and vars is an instance of
SCons Variables . The
env and
vars , if given, will be populated with default values of construction variables and command line variables provided with
decls .

section.para:
The prototype of the
Commit method is
Parameters are summarized in the following table

tr.td:
A
SCons Environment object to be populated with default values of construction variables defined by GVar variables declared here.

A
SCons Variables object to be populated with new variables defined by GVar variables.

If
True, the command-line options declared by GVar variables are created.

If
True (default) create and return a
_GVars object for further operation on variables and their values. If
False ,
None is returned.

section.para:
The method returns a new
_GVars object if
gvars parameter was
True (default). Otherwise it returns
None .

If you decide to not spawn
_GVars when Committing, the committed declarations may always be converted to
_GVars at a later stage:
section.programlisting: from SConsGnu import GVars vars = GVars._GVars(decls)

section.title: Updating scons environment
section.para:
The final step of the three-step procedure outlined at the end of
is to update scons environment with GVar values. This is achieved with the
_GVars.UpdateEnvironment method. Let
gv be an instance of
_GVars ,
env be an instance of
SCons Environment , and
variables be an instance of
SCons Variables . We may pump values from command line variables and options to their associated construction variables in
env as follows

The prototype of
UpdateEnvironment is following
The parameters are summarized in the following table

tr.td:
A
SCons Environment object to be updated.

A
SCons Variables object with
SCons variables to retrieve values from. If
None, then
SCons Variables are not taken into account.

If
True ,
command-line options are taken into account when updating
env . If False, the command-line options are not taken into account.

Passed verbatim to an internal method
update_env_from_vars() . See API documentation for details.

section.title: Accessing GVar values
section.para:
Values assigned to GVars get stored in their associated variables in a SCons environment. For example, a value of GVar
foo may be stored in a construction variable
xyz . The name of the associatted construction variable (
xyz ) may be other than the name of its GVar and the mapping from GVars to SCon environment does not have to be obvious. If we have a number of such variables and we keep track of GVar names only, then accessing their values directly in SCons environment may be cumbersome.

We may use
proxy to access GVar values using their original names. A proxy object is a thin wrapper around SCons environment which internally transforms GVar names to the names of their associated construction variables. In the previous example you would query such a proxy for the value of
foo and it would return the value of construction variable
xyz .

example.title: Accessing GVar values via proxy
example.para:
In this example, we create a GVar variable named
foo which associates command line variable
foo and construction variable
env_foo . We then create a proxy object to access the value of variable using its original name
foo .
example.programlisting:
from SConsGnu.GVars import GVarDeclsU
env = Environment() var = Variables()
decls = GVarDeclsU( foo = { 'env_key' : 'env_foo', 'var_key' : 'foo' } ) gv = decls.Commit(env, var) gv.UpdateEnvironment(env, var)
# create proxy object proxy = gv.EnvProxy(env) # access variable via proxy print "foo: %s" % proxy['foo']
example.para: The above script may be tested as follows ptomulik@tea:$scons-Q foo="it's a foo" foo: it's a foo scons: `.' is up to date.

section.para: The proxy object provides dict-like access to GVars as well as substitutions. In the above example, you may freely replace the line print "foo: %s" % proxy['foo'] with print proxy.subst("foo: $foo")

Note, that the proxy object does not wrap all the functionality of the environment, so most functions are not available. It just wraps dict access and the
subst method. So other methods, including builders, pseudobuilders etc. are not available via proxy.

section.title: Putting it all together
section.para:
In this section we'll walk through a complete example. We'll define three GVar variables:
prefix - installation prefix,
exec_prefix - installation prefix for executable files,
bindir - directory for installing executable programs that users can run.
To make our live a little bit more complicated, we'll associate the following construction variables (ENV), command line variables (VAR) and command line options (OPT) with our GVars

tr.td: GNU_PREFIX
PREFIX
--prefix/opt_prefix
GNU_EXEC_PREFIX
EXEC_PREFIX
--exec-prefix/opt_exec_prefix
GNU_BINDIR
BINDIR
--bindir/opt_bindir

section.para: The complete code of a SConstruct file using these variables is shown in the following example

example.title: Complete example involving GVars
example.programlisting:
# SConstruct from SConsGnu import GVars decls = GVars.GVarDeclsU( prefix = { 'env_key' : 'GNU_PREFIX', 'var_key' : 'PREFIX', 'opt_key' : 'opt_prefix', 'option' : '--prefix', 'default' : '/usr/local', 'type' : 'string', 'help' : 'installation prefix' }, exec_prefix = { 'env_key' : 'GNU_EXEC_PREFIX', 'var_key' : 'EXEC_PREFIX', 'opt_key' : 'opt_exec_prefix', 'option' : '--exec-prefix', 'default' : '$prefix', 'type' : 'string', 'help' : 'installation prefix for executable files' }, bindir = { 'env_key' : 'GNU_BINDIR', 'var_key' : 'BINDIR', 'opt_key' : 'opt_bindir', 'option' : '--bindir', 'default' : '$exec_prefix/bin', 'type' : 'string', 'help' : 'directory for installing executable programs that users can run' } ) env = Environment() var = Variables() gv = decls.Commit(env, var, True) gv.UpdateEnvironment(env, var, True)
# Create proxy to access GVars using their original names proxy = gv.EnvProxy(env)
# Print values. print proxy.subst('prefix: $prefix') print proxy.subst('exec_prefix: $exec_prefix') print proxy.subst('bindir: $bindir')

section.para:
Let's play for a while with the
. First we'll check the default values
section.screen: ptomulik@tea:$ scons -Q prefix: /usr/local exec_prefix: /usr/local bindir: /usr/local/bin scons: `.' is up to date.
section.para:
Now, set custom
exec_prefix via comman line variable:
section.screen: ptomulik@tea:$ scons -Q EXEC_PREFIX='$PREFIX/exec' prefix: /usr/local exec_prefix: /usr/local/exec bindir: /usr/local/exec/bin scons: `.' is up to date.
section.para: And same thing with command line option:
section.screen: ptomulik@tea:$ scons -Q --exec-prefix='$opt_prefix/exec' prefix: /usr/local exec_prefix: /usr/local/exec bindir: /usr/local/exec/bin scons: `.' is up to date.
section.para: If we specify both, the command line variable and the command line option, the option takes precedence
section.screen: ptomulik@tea:$ scons -Q --exec-prefix='$opt_prefix/exec_o' EXEC_PREFIX='$PREFIX/exec_v' prefix: /usr/local exec_prefix: /usr/local/exec_o bindir: /usr/local/exec_o/bin scons: `.' is up to date.
section.para:
Help strings for options are added automatically, we may see them under
Local Options section when running
scons -h .
section.screen:
ptomulik@tea:$scons -h usage: scons [OPTION] [TARGET] ...
SCons Options: <.... lot of options here ...> Local Options: --exec-prefix=OPT_EXEC_PREFIX installation prefix for executable files --prefix=OPT_PREFIX installation prefix --bindir=OPT_BINDIR directory for installing executable programs that users can run

section.title: Documenting Command Line variables
section.para:
Command line variables, as opposed to command line options, have no help strings generated by default. To generate help for command line variables, one may invoke
GenerateVariablesHelpText method on
_GVars variables:

Note, that the above declaration shadows local options (our
--prefix for example), such that they're not available anymore at help screen. To circumvent this problem, we may dedicate separate option to print help for command line variables.

example.title: Documenting command line variables
example.programlisting: AddOption( '--help-variables', dest='help_variables', action='store_true', help='print help for CLI variables' ) if GetOption('help_variables'): print gv.GenerateVariablesHelpText(var, env) Exit(0)

section.para:
If we integrate this snippet into SConscript from
, then running
scons --help-variables yields
section.screen:
ptomulik@tea:$ scons -Q --help-variables
EXEC_PREFIX: installation prefix for executable files default: ${PREFIX} actual: /usr/local
PREFIX: installation prefix default: /usr/local actual: /usr/local
BINDIR: directory for installing executable programs that users can run default: ${EXEC_PREFIX}/bin actual: /usr/local/bin

section.title: Saving command line variables to a file
section.para:
Command line variables associatted with our GVars may be saved to a file with
SaveVariables method.

Note, that this saves only values changed via command line (defaults are not saved). This takes into account input from a command line variable and a command line option associated with a given GVar. In any case, however, the value is saved as it was set to a command line variable.

example.title: Saving GVars to file
example.para:
If you integrate the following code snippet to the SConscript file from
, gv.SaveVariables(var, '.scons_variables', env) then we have the following behavior
example.screen: ptomulik@tea:$ scons --prefix=/opt EXEC_PREFIX='${PREFIX}/exec' ptomulik@tea:$ cat .scons_variables EXEC_PREFIX = '${PREFIX}/exec' PREFIX = '/opt'

section.title: Loading command line variables from file
section.para:
This is done in standard way, that is by using the feature of
SCons Variables . The only thing that has to be done is to provide
file parameter when creating command line variables

section.title: Variables for installation directories
section.para:
GNU coding standards introduce special automake variables which abstract installation directories for certain categories of files (binaries, documentation, etc.), see
Installation Directory Variables section of the official documentation. The
scons-gnu-build has a predefined set of GVar variables (see
) with similar purpose.

Standard Installation Directory Variables are implemented in
AcDirVars submodule:
In order to have Installation Directory Variables activated you need to append predefined directory variable declarations to your current set of GVars declarations:
section.programlisting: from SConsGnu import AcDirVars # ... # Assume, decls is an instance of _GVarDecls decls.update(AcDirVars.DeclareGVars()) # ...
section.para:
The remaining steps are identical to those described in
. Let's take a look at complete example.

example.title: Using Installation Directory Variables
example.para:
In this complete example we activate all the standard directory variables. We store them in
'.scons_variables' file and add
--help-variables option to display help for all the defined command line variables.
example.programlisting:
# SConstruct from SConsGnu import GVars, AcDirVars env = Environment() var = Variables('.scons_variables') decls = AcDirVars.DeclareGVars() gv = decls.Commit(env, var, True) # Add help AddOption( '--help-variables', dest='help_variables', action='store_true', help='print help for CLI variables' ) if GetOption('help_variables'): print gv.GenerateVariablesHelpText(var, env) Exit(0)
gv.UpdateEnvironment(env, var, True) gv.SaveVariables(var, '.scons_variables', env)
example.para: Let's print a help message to see new options generated by our Directory Variables
example.screen:
ptomulik@barakus:$ scons -Q --help usage: scons [OPTION] [TARGET] ...
SCons Options: < .. lot of options here .. > Local Options: --docdir=DIR The directory for installing documentation files (other than Info) for this package. --man1ext=DIR --sharedstatedir=DIR The directory for installing architecture-independent data files which the programs modify while they run. < .. and plenty of the other local options .. >

section.para:
The values of directory variables may be accessed in SCons scripts via environment object
env . .

By default, environment variables associated with Directory Variables have 'GVAR_' prefix. This may be changed when declaring the Directory Variables. The
DeclareGVars function has an argument named
env_key_transform which specifies how the GVar name should be converted to the name of associated environment variable. For example, to use original GVar name one has to": AcDirVars.DeclareGVars(env_key_transform = lambda x : x)

The function has also parameters which control transformation of CLI variable names, CLI options keys and names, and filtering which of all the standard Directory Variables should be declared. This is summarized in the following table

tr.td:
Function or lambda (
name_filter(name) -> boolean ) used to filter-out unwanted variables. Only these variables are processed, for which
name_filter returns
True . May be used to select only some of the standard directory variables to be activated.
Function or lambda used to transform canonical GVar names to keys used for corresponding construction variables in a SCons environment
Function or lambda used to transform canonical GVar names to keys used for corresponding SCons command-line variables variable=value
Function or lambda used to transform canonical GVar names to keys used for corresponding SCons command-line options --option=value
Function or lambda used to transform canonical GVar names to option names

section.title: Autoconf-like tests
section.para:
Autoconf-like tests are implemented using the existing feature of scons - the
Multi-Platform Configuration (Autoconf Functionality) . The scons-gnu-build defines several SConf tests corresponding to macros implemented by
autoconf . These tests are scattered over few modules. Before using tests from a given module, one have to add them to a SConf object. The template code that uses autoconf-like tests is the following # SConstruct from SConsGnu import XxxChecks, YyyChecks env = Environment() cfg = Configure(env)
# Add tests from modules XxxChecks and YyyChecks cfg.AddTests(XxxChecks.Tests()) cfg.AddTests(YyyChecks.Tests())
# Perform tests implemented in XxxChecks and YyyChecks modules ... res1 = cfg.AcFoo(...)
# more tests if needed ...
# Finish configuration env = cfg.Finish() where
XxxChecks is a module implementing particular tests. From now on you may use
cfg object to perform all the checks defined by
XxxChecks module.

section.title: Alternative programs
section.para: These tests check for the presence or behavior of particular programs. They are used to choose between several alternative programs and to decide what to do once one has been chosen. If there is no macro specifically defined to check for a program you need, and you don't need to check for any special properties of it, then you can use one of the general program-check tests.

The tests for alternative programs are implemented in
AcProgChecks submodule. In addition to the tests, the module provides declaration of several
GVars that may be used in conjuction with the tests. The variables for alternative programs are actually provided by
AcProgVars submodule but they are also available directly via AcProgChecks for convenience.

The SCons script which checks for alternative programs will usually contain statements such as # SConstruct from SConsGnu import AcProgChecks
env = Environment() # create an environment cfg = Configure(env) # create SConf object cfg.AddTests(AcProgChecks.Tests()) # add tests for alternative programs
# Define GVars that will be used in conjuction with our test(s) later. decls = AcProgChecks.DeclareGVars(name_filter = ['AWK']) var = Variables() gvs = decls.Commit(env, var, True) gvs.UpdateEnvironment(env, var, True) proxy = gvs.EnvProxy(env)
# Now we can perform tests implemented by AcProgChecks module, for example: proxy['AWK'] = cfg.AcProgAwk(proxy['AWK'])
# Finish configuration env = cfg.Finish()
# Print the result print "AWK: %r" % proxy['AWK']

The above code snippet checks for AWK program. If user invokes it without additional command-line variables, the script will perform check and select the awk program automatically. The result will be stored in GVar variable named
AWK . If, however, user will set the commandline variable
AWK , the value of
AWK commandline variable will be used instead. For example ptomulik@tea:$ scons scons: Reading SConscript files ... Checking for awk... gawk AWK: ['gawk'] < ... > and ptomulik@tea:$ scons AWK=myawk scons: Reading SConscript files ... Checking for awk... myawk AWK: ['myawk'] < ... >

Most of the test functions have a parameter named
selection . If this parameter is provided and its value differ from default, then real test is not performed in fact and the function simply returns the value of
selection parameter. This simplifies overriding the checks with values provided by user (usually via commandline).

section.title: Particular program checks
section.para: These tests check for particular programs, whether they exist, and in some cases whether they support certain features.

section.title: AcProgLex
section.para:
Corresponds to
AC_PROG_LEX autoconf macro.
Synopsis: lex, lexroot, lexlibs, yytextptr = cfg.AcProgLex(selection=SConsGnu.AcProgVars._auto, programs=None, lexroots=None, lexlibs=None)
The parameters are summarized in the following table

tr.td:
A value of
lex to be returned by the function. If left default, the function will perform check, select the program automatically, and return the result of the check as
lex . In this case the function returns tuple
(lex, None, None) as it's not possible to determine lexroot and lexlibs without running real tests.

List of program names to look for (in order). If
None (default), the default list
[ 'flex', 'lex' ] will be used

When
lex is invoked without
-o option, it writes its output to default file named
lex.yy.c or
lexyy.c depending on version. In such case, the string
lex.yy or
lexyy is called the lex file root. The
AcProgLex method determines the lex file root and returns it as
lexroot . The
lexroots parameter lists possible choices to pickup from. If it is set to
None the default list
[ 'lex.yy.c', 'lexyy.c' ] is used.

List of lex library names to be checked. The function tries to link a
*.c file generated by
lex against each of the libraries from list. The first library, for which the compilation succeeds is returned as output
lexlibs value.

Source code of a lex script to be used when performing checks. If not
None (default) a default script will be used.

section.para: Return values:

tr.td:
Name of the
lex program detected.

Root part of the
*.c file name generated by lex when invoked without
-o option.
lexlibs

List of libraries needed to compile a program generated with
lex.
yytextptr

True if
yytext is defined as pointer. Lex can declare
yytext either as a pointer or an array. The default is implementation-dependent. This return value allows to figure out which it is, since not all implementations provide
%pointer and
%array declarations.

example.title: Usage example for AcProgLex
example.programlisting: # SConstruct from SConsGnu import AcProgChecks env = Environment() # create an environment cfg = Configure(env) # create SConf object cfg.AddTests(AcProgChecks.Tests()) # add tests for alternative programs lex, lexroot, lexlibs, yytextptr = cfg.AcProgLex() # perform the check env = cfg.Finish() # finish configuration # print the returned values print "lex: %r" % lex print "lexroot: %r" % lexroot print "lexlibs: %r" % lexlibs print "yytextptr: %r" % yytextptr
example.screen:
ptomulik@tea:$scons scons: Reading SConscript files ... Checking for flex... flex Checking for lex output file root... lex.yy Checking for lex library... -lfl Checking whether yytext is a pointer... yes lex: ['flex'] lexroot: 'lex.yy' lexlibs: ['fl'] yytextptr: True
< ... >
